name: 比較教育研究
description:
1.	培養研究生具備教育問題的比較分析能力。
2.	培養研究生探究其他國家和區域的教育政策與制度。
3.	協助研究生具備批判教育並有應用整合的觀點能力，以綜合研判教育發展方向。
goals: 培養研究生具備教育問題的比較分析能力。
培養研究生探究其他國家和區域的教育政策與制度。
協助研究生具備批判教育並有應用整合的觀點能力，以綜合研判教育發展方向。
syllabus:
**Course details:**

Week 1: Introduction

Week 2: Education reform: from past to present

Required readings:

Tyack, D., & Cuban, L. (1995). _Tinkering toward Utopia: a century of public school reform_. Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press

Levin, B., & Young, J. (2000). The rhetoric of educational reform. J_ournal of Comparative Policy Analysis: Research and Practice_, 2(2), 189-209. Retrieved from [http://www.informaworld.com/10.1080/13876980008412642.](http://www.informaworld.com/10.1080/13876980008412642.) doi:10.1080/13876980008412642

Week 3: Global Education Reform Movement (GERM)

Required readings:

Graham, J. (2013). Editorial: Education reform and its antidotes. _Professional Voice (Global Educational Reform Movement)_, 9(3), 5-10.

Sahlberg, P. (2016). The Global Educational Reform Movement and Its Impact on Schooling. In K. Mundy, A. Green, B. Lingard, & A. Verger (Eds.), _The Handbook of Global Education Policy_ (pp. 128-144). Chichester, England: Wiley Blackwell.

Week 4: Education Reform: Asian Perspectives?

Required readings:

Hallinger, P. (2010). Making education reform happen: is there an 'Asian' way? _School Leadership & Management_, 30(5), 401-418. doi:10.1080/13632434.2010.502524

Lai, M., & Lo, L. N. K. (2007). Teacher professionalism in educational reform: the experiences of Hong Kong and Shanghai. _Compare: A Journal of Comparative and International Education_, 37(1), 53-68.

Week 5: Case study 1: Education reform in Singapore

Required readings:

Gopinathan, S. (2007). Globalization, the Singapore Developmental State and Education Policy: A Thesis Revisited. _Globalization, Societies and Education_, 5(1), 53-70.

Tan, J. (2010). Education in Singapore. In T. Chong (Ed.), _Management of success: Singapore revisited_ (pp. 288-308). Singapore: Institute of Southeast Asian Studies.

Week 6: Case study 2: Education reform in Taiwan

Required readings:

Lin, T.-B., Wang, L.-Y., Li, J.-Y., & Chang, C. (2014). Pursuing Quality Education: The Lessons from the Education Reform in Taiwan. _The Asia Pacific Education Researcher_, 23(4), 813-822.

Chou, C. P., & Ching, G. (2012). T_aiwan Education at the Crossroad When Globalization Meets Localization_. New York: Palgrave Macmillan.

Week 7: e-Learning: Watching documentaries on education reform (If there is reason to study)

Week 8: Essay 1 submission

Week 9: Media and Information Literacy: a review of the development of a concept

Required readings:

Buckingham, D. (2003). _Media education: literacy, learning and contemporary culture_. Cambridge: Polity.

Grizzle, A., & Calvo, M. C. T. (Eds.). (2013). _Media and Information Literacy: Policy and Strategy Guidelines_. Paris France: UNESCO.

Week 10: Media and Information Literacy: different theories

Required readings:

Buckingham, D. (2003). _Media education: literacy, learning and contemporary culture_. Cambridge: Polity.

Lin, T.-B., Li, J.-Y., Deng, F., & Lee, L. (2013). Understanding New Media Literacy: An Explorative Theoretical Framework. _Educational Technology & Society_, 16(4), 160-170.

Burn, A., & Durran, J. (2007). _Media literacy in schools: practice, production and progression_. London: Paul Champman Publishing Ltd.

Week 11: Media and Information Literacy in Asia

Required readings:

Cheung, C. K. (Ed.) (2009). _Media Education in Asia_. Dordercht, Netherland: Springer.

Lin, T.-B., & Chen, V. (2018). Diverse Discourse, Limited Action: Media Literacy in East Asia. Retrieved from [https://www.wise-qatar.org/diverse-discourse-limited-action-media-literacy-in-east-asia](https://www.wise-qatar.org/diverse-discourse-limited-action-media-literacy-in-east-asia)

Lin, T.-B., Mokhtar, I. A., & Wang, L.-Y. (2015). The construct of media and information literacy in Singapore education system: global trends and local policies. _Asia Pacific Journal of Education_, 35(4), 423-437. doi:10.1080/02188791.2013.860012

Chen, D.-T., Lin, T.-B., Li, J.-Y., & Lee, L. (2018). Establishing the norm of new media literacy of Singaporean students: Implications to policy and pedagogy. _Computers & Education_(124), 1-13.

Week 12: Case Study 3: Media and Information Literacy in Taiwan

Required readings:

Lin, T.-B. (2009). Navigating through the mist: media literacy education in Taiwan. In C.-K. Cheung (Ed.), _Media Education in Asia_ (pp. 165-184). Heidelberg: Springer.

Lin, T.-B. (2009). New media and media literacy: a case study of media education policy in Taiwan. In M. Leaning (Ed.), _Issues in information and media literacy: criticism, history and policy_ (pp. 49-70). Santa Rosa, CA: Informing Science Press.

Week 13: e-Learning: Self-study on the UNESCO agenda of Media and Information Literacy

Week 14: Essay 2 submission

Week 15: The rise of NESTs

Required readings:

Moussu, L., & Llurda, E. (2008). Non-native English-speaking English teachers: history and research. _Language teaching_, 41(3), 315-348.

Reis, D. S. (2011). Non-native English-speaking teachers ( NNESTs) and professional legitimacy: a sociocultural theoretical perspective on identity transformation. _International journal of sociology of language_, 208, 139–160. doi:DOI 10.1515/IJSL.2011.016

Kim, H.-K. (2011). Native speakerism affecting nonnative English teachers’ identity formation: A critical perspective. _English Teaching_, 66(4), 53-71.

Wang, L.-Y., & Lin, T.-B. (2013). The representation of professionalism in native English-speaking teachers recruitment policies: A comparative study of Hong Kong, Japan, Korea and Taiwan. _English Teaching: Practice and Critique_, 12(3), 5-22.

Week 16: Case Study 4: NESTs in Taiwanese context

Required readings:

Luo, W.-H. (2007). A Study of Native English-speaking Teacher Programs in Elementary Schools in Taiwan. Asia Pacific Education Review, 8(2), 311-320.

Lin, T.-B., Wang, L.-Y., & Wang, M. (2018). Diverse Interpretations on Nativeness but Unanimous Subscription to Native-speakerism: Identity of Future Non-native English Teachers in Taiwan. Journal of Asia TEFL, 15(3), 603-617.

Wang, L.-Y., & Lin, T.-B. (2014). Exploring the identity of pre-service NNESTs in Taiwan: A social relationally approach. English Teaching: Practice and Critique, 13(3), 5-29.

Lin, T.-B., & Wang, L. (2016). Native English-Speaking Teachers (NESTs) in Taiwan: policies and practices. In F. Copland, S. Garton,& S. Mann (Eds.), LETs and NESTs: Voices, Views and Vignettes (pp. 151-168). UK: British Council.

Week 17: e-Learning: Self-study on the policies related to NESTs in Taiwan

Week 18: Essay 3 submission
